content:
TITLE: Accessing Properties in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to access properties using bracket and dot notations in Jora. This example retrieves the title of the first post in an array.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/intro.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
posts[0].title
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Filtering Arrays in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to filter an array of users based on a condition. This example filters users who are older than 30 years.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/intro.md#2025-04-18_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
users.[age > 30]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Calculating Average Age by Occupation using Jora
DESCRIPTION: This Jora query groups people by occupation, calculates the average age for each group, and sorts the results by average age in descending order. It demonstrates grouping, aggregation, and sorting operations in Jora.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/complex-examples.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
people
  .group(=> occupation)
  .({ 
    occupation: key,
    averageAge: value.avg(=> age)
  })
  .sort(averageAge desc)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating Custom Query Factory with Jora Setup in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to create a custom query factory using Jora's setup method. This approach allows for consistent application of custom settings across various queries, which is recommended for scenarios requiring custom methods or assertions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/api.md#2025-04-18_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

// Create a query factory with common settings
const createQuery = jora.setup({ /* methods, assertions */ });

// Create a query
const query = createQuery('foo.bar', { /* options as for jora() without "methods" and "assertions" */ });

// Perform the query
const result = query(data, context);
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using Methods and Functions in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of methods and functions in Jora. This example sorts users by name in ascending order and then groups them by name.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/intro.md#2025-04-18_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
users.sort(name asc).group(=> name)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Initializing and Executing Jora Query in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to import the Jora library, create a query with options, and execute it on data with a context. This snippet showcases the basic usage of Jora for query creation and execution.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/api.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

// Create a query
const query = jora('foo.bar', { /* ...options */ });

// Perform the query
const result = query(data, context);
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Demonstrating Jora's Data Safety Features
DESCRIPTION: Examples showing how Jora handles undefined properties safely and can generate output without input data, demonstrating its non-mutating nature.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/discovery/text/getting-started.md#2025-04-18_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
jora('.foo.bar')({ a: 42 }) // undefined
jora('2 + 2')() // 4
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using Built-in Jora Methods for Data Manipulation
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the use of built-in Jora methods 'group()', 'sort()', and 'size()' for grouping data by name, creating an object with name and records, and sorting by record size in descending order.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/methods.md#2025-04-18_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
group(=> name)
    .({ name: key, records: value })
    .sort(records.size() desc)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Mapping Syntax in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Shows the basic syntax for mapping in Jora using the .(expr) notation and the alternative map() method approach.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/map.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
.(expr)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Demonstrating Jora Method Syntax
DESCRIPTION: Shows the basic syntax for invoking methods in Jora. The expression before the method is passed as the first argument to the method.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/methods.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
expr.method(...args)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Setting Up Custom Jora Methods in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to enhance Jora queries by defining custom methods using the jora.setup() function. This example creates a custom method 'customMethod' that can be used in Jora queries.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/methods.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

// Create a custom setup for queries
const queryWithCustomMethods = jora.setup({
    methods: {
        customMethod($) { /* implement custom logic here */ }
    }
});

// Use the custom query factory
queryWithCustomMethods('foo.customMethod()')(data, context);
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Mapping Property Values in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Example of extracting property values from an array of objects using Jora's mapping functionality.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/map.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$input: [
    { "baz": 1 },
    { "baz": 2 },
    { "baz": 3 }
];

$input.(baz)
// Result: [ 1, 2, 3 ]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Creating a Jora Query Function
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how the Jora factory function converts a query string into a function that can be executed on data.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/discovery/text/getting-started.md#2025-04-18_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

typeof jora('query') // "function"
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Jora Query API Example
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the core API for creating and performing Jora queries, showing how to create a query object and execute it against data with an optional context.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/README.md#2025-04-18_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

// create a query
const query = jora('foo.bar');

// perform a query
const result = query(data, context);
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Jora Function Syntax
DESCRIPTION: Examples of different supported function declaration formats in Jora
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/functions.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
=> expr
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$arg => expr
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
() => expr
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
($arg) => expr
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
($arg1, $arg2) => expr
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Variable Definitions in Filter Scope in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to define and use variables within a filtering operation. Variables can be used to store intermediate values and simplify filtering conditions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/variables.md#2025-04-18_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
[1, 2, 3].[$num: $; $num % 2]
// Result: [1, 3]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining and Using Variables in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the basic syntax for defining variables in Jora. Variables can be defined with explicit values (using $ident: expression;) or with a shorthand syntax ($ident;) that assigns the property value with the same name.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/variables.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$foo: 123;          // Define `$foo` variable
$bar;               // Shorthand for `$bar: bar;`
$baz: $foo + $bar;  // Definitions may be used in following expressions
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using Math Methods in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Examples of various mathematical operations using Math methods.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/methods-builtin.md#2025-04-18_snippet_26

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
-123 | abs()
// Result: 123
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
'hello world'.abs()
// Result: NaN
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
(-1).acos()
// Result: 3.141592653589793
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
1.acos()
// Result: 0
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
'hello world'.acos()
// Result: NaN
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
64.cbrt()
// Result: 4
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
3.123.ceil()
// Result: 4
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
2.exp()
// Result: 7.38905609893065
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
(-1).exp()
// Result: 0.36787944117144233
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Pipeline Operator in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the pipeline operator for chaining expressions and simplifying queries
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/operators.md#2025-04-18_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
1.5 | floor() + ceil()
// Result: 3
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
(a + b).round()

```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
a + b | round()
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
{ foo: 1, bar: 2, baz: 3 }.(foo + bar + baz)
// Result: 6
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
{ foo: 1, bar: 2, baz: 3 } | foo + bar + baz
// Result: 6
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
{ a: 10, b: [2, 3, 4] } | $k: a; b.($ * $k)
// Result: [20, 30, 40]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Combined Dot Notation with Filtering and Aggregation in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates combining dot notation with filtering and aggregation functions to perform complex queries on array data.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/dot-notation.md#2025-04-18_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$items: [
    { name: 'foo', value: 1 },
    { name: 'bar', value: 2 },
    { name: 'baz', value: 3 },
    { name: 'foo', value: 4 }
];

$items.[name = 'foo'].value.sum()
// Result: 5
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using reduce() Method in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates reduce() method usage for array reduction operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/methods-builtin.md#2025-04-18_snippet_18

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
[1, 5, 2, 3, 4].reduce(=>$ > $$ ? $ : $$)
// Result: 5
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Pattern Matching with match() in Jora
DESCRIPTION: The match() method is similar to String#match() in JavaScript. It allows matching a string against a RegExp or string pattern, with options to return all matches. The method returns detailed information about each match.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/methods-builtin.md#2025-04-18_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
'abcabc'.match('bc')
// Result: {
//     matched: ['bc'],
//     start: 1,
//     end: 3,
//     input: 'abcabc',
//     groups: null,
// }
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
'abcabc'.match('bc', true) // matchAll parameter is true
// Result: [{
//     matched: ['bc'],
//     start: 1,
//     end: 3,
//     input: 'abcabc',
//     groups: null,
// }, {
//     matched: ['bc'],
//     start: 4,
//     end: 6,
//     input: 'abcabc',
//     groups: null,
// }]
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
'abc123a45'.match(/a(bc)?(?<numbers>\d+)/)
// Result: {
//     matched: ['abc123', 'bc', '123'],
//     start: 0,
//     end: 6,
//     input: 'abc123a45',
//     groups: { numbers: '123' },
// }
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
'abc123a45'.match(/a(bc)?(?<numbers>\d+)/g) // the RegExp has 'g' flag
// Result: [{
//     matched: ['abc123', 'bc', '123'],
//     start: 0,
//     end: 6,
//     input: 'abc123a45',
//     groups: { numbers: '123' },
// }, {
//     matched: ['a45', undefined, '45'],
//     start: 6,
//     end: 9,
//     input: 'abc123a45',
//     groups: { numbers: '45' },
// }]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Arithmetic Operators in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates arithmetic operations including addition, subtraction, multiplication, division and modulo with both numbers and arrays
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/operators.md#2025-04-18_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
// Add numbers
1 + 2 // 3

// Add arrays
[1, 2, 3] + [2, 3, 4] // [1, 2, 3, 4]

// Subtract numbers
10 - 5 // 5

// Subtract arrays
[1, 2, 3] - [2, 3] // [1]

// Subtract from array
[1, 2, 3] - 2 // [1, 3]

// Multiply numbers
2 * 3 // 6

// Divide numbers
10 / 2 // 5

// Modulo
7 % 3 // 1
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Logical Operators in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates logical operators including OR, AND, NOT, nullish coalescing, IS, IN, and HAS operators
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/operators.md#2025-04-18_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
// Logical OR
true or false   // true
[] or false     // false
[1, 2] or false // [1, 2]

// Logical AND
true and false  // false
true and true   // true
{} and "ok"     // {}

// Logical NOT
not true // false
no false // true
not []   // true
not [1]  // false

// Nullish coalescing
null ?? 1      // 1
undefined ?? 1 // 1
false ?? 1     // false
1234 ?? 1      // 1234

// IS operator
[] is array    // true
[] is number   // false
{} is (boolean or string) // false

// IN operator
1 in [1, 2, 3] // true
4 in [1, 2, 3] // false

// HAS operator
[1, 2, 3] has 1 // true
[1, 2, 3] has 4 // false

// NOT IN operator
1 not in [1, 2, 3] // false
4 not in [1, 2, 3] // true

// HAS NO operator
[1, 2, 3] has no 1 // false
[1, 2, 3] has no 4 // true
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Filtering an Array of Objects by Property Value in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating how to filter an array of objects based on a property value, specifically keeping only books with a price less than or equal to 10.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/filter.md#2025-04-18_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$input: [
  { "title": "Book 1", "price": 5 },
  { "title": "Book 2", "price": 15 },
  { "title": "Book 3", "price": 7 },
  { "title": "Book 4", "price": 12 }
];

$input.[price <= 10]
// Result:
// [
//   { "title": "Book 1", "price": 5 },
//   { "title": "Book 3", "price": 7 }
// ]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Defining Multi-Property Sorting Function in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to create a sorting function that sorts by multiple properties in different orders, with a JavaScript equivalent provided.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/sort.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
foo asc, bar desc // JS equivalent: (a, b) =>
                  //       a.foo > b.foo ? 1 : a.foo < b.foo ? -1 :
                  //       a.bar < b.bar ? 1 : a.bar > b.bar ? -1 :
                  //       0
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Comparison Operators in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Shows usage of comparison operators including equals, not equals, less than, greater than, and match operators
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/operators.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
// Equals
1 = 1 // true
'a' = 'b' // false

// Not equals
1 != 2 // true
'a' != 'a' // false

// Less than
1 < 2 // true
2 < 1 // false

// Less than or equal to
1 <= 1 // true
2 <= 1 // false

// Greater than
2 > 1 // true
1 > 2 // false

// Greater than or equal to
2 >= 2 // true
1 >= 2 // false

// Match operator
'hello' ~= /l+/ // true
'world' ~= => size() > 3 // true
'foo' ~= null // true
'bar' ~= 123 // false
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Jora Filtering Syntax
DESCRIPTION: The basic syntax for filtering arrays in Jora using the square bracket notation. This allows filtering elements based on a condition specified in the block.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/filter.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
.[block]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Working with Variables in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use variables in Jora queries. This example assigns the oldest user to a variable and then retrieves their name.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/intro.md#2025-04-18_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$oldestUser: users.max(age desc);
$oldestUser.name
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Group Method Syntax in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the basic syntax for the group() method which takes a keyFunction and optional valueFunction as parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/group.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
.group(keyFunction[, valueFunction])
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Mapping Arrays in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to map an array of users to create a new array with full names. This example concatenates the first and last names of each user.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/intro.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
users.(name.first + ' ' + name.last)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Object Literal Syntax in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates the basic syntax for creating object literals in Jora, which supports keys with or without quotation marks similar to JSON5 and JavaScript.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/object-literal.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
{
    "name": "John Doe",
    'age': 30,
    isActive: true
}
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Map Method Syntax in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use the map() method in Jora with a function parameter for transformation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/map.md#2025-04-18_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
.map(fn) // or .map(=> expr)
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Jora Book Search Function
DESCRIPTION: Complex example showing function usage with nested scopes and array filtering
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/functions.md#2025-04-18_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$books: [
    { id: 1, title: "To Kill a Mockingbird", author: "Harper Lee" },
    { id: 2, title: "1984", author: "George Orwell" },
    { id: 3, title: "The Great Gatsby", author: "F. Scott Fitzgerald" }
];
$getBook: $id => $books[=> id = $id];
3 | $getBook()
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Grouping by Computed Property in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates grouping numbers into even and odd categories using a computed property.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/group.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
.group(=> $ % 2 ? 'odd' : 'even')
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Filtering an Array of Numbers in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to filter an array of numbers to include only those greater than or equal to 3 using the square bracket notation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/filter.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5].[$ >= 3]
// Result: [3, 4, 5]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Property Access Using Dot Notation in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates simple property access using dot notation to retrieve a value from an object.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/dot-notation.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
person.name // Accesses the `name` property of the `person` object
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using Spread Operator in Jora Array Literals
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the spread operator (...) in array literals to include all elements of existing arrays. It demonstrates merging two arrays and using spread in a reduce() method.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/array-literal.md#2025-04-18_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$first: [1, 2, 3];
$second: [4, 5, 6];

[...$first, ...$second]
// Result: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$input: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9];
$input.reduce(=>$ % 2 ? [...$$, $] : $$, [])
// Result: [1, 3, 5, 7, 9]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Complex Assertion Expressions in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates how to create complex assertion expressions using logical operators and parentheses for grouping in Jora queries.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/assertions.md#2025-04-18_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
is not assertion
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
is (assertion and assertion)
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
is (assertion or not assertion)
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
is not (assertion and assertion)
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
is (assertion and (assertion or assertion))
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Unique Value Generation with Jora Mapping
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how Jora's mapping automatically returns unique values from arrays.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/map.md#2025-04-18_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
[ 1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3 ].() // .() is equivalent to .($)
// Result: [1, 2, 3]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Basic Children Recursion in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to recursively extract all child objects from a nested structure.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/recursive-map.md#2025-04-18_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
..children
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implementing Custom Methods and Assertions in Jora Queries
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates two approaches for enhancing Jora queries with custom methods and assertions. The first method uses the setup() function to create a reusable query factory, while the second defines extensions ad hoc on a basic query factory call.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/api.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

// Create a custom setup for queries
const queryWithCustomMethods = jora.setup({
    methods: {
        customMethod($) { /* implement custom logic here */ }
    },
    assertions: {
        odd: '$ % 2 = 1'
    }
});

// Use the custom query factory
queryWithCustomMethods('foo.customMethod(is odd)')(data, context);
```

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

// Define extensions on a query created for basic setup
const result = jora('foo.customMethod(is odd)', {
    methods: {
        customMethod($) { /* implement custom logic here */ }
    },
    assertions: {
        odd: '$ % 2 = 1'
    }
})(data, context);
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Using pick() Method in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Examples of using pick() method to get values by key or index from arrays and objects.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/methods-builtin.md#2025-04-18_snippet_17

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
[1, 2, 3, 4].pick(2)
// Result: 3
```

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
{ foo: 1, bar: 2 }.pick('bar')
// Result: 2
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Query-level Assertion Example in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use variables storing functions as assertions in Jora queries. This example defines an 'odd' assertion and applies it to an array of numbers.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/assertions.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$odd: => $ % 2;
[1, 2, 3, 4, 5].({ num: $, odd: is $odd })
// Result: [
//     { "num": 1, "odd": true },
//     { "num": 2, "odd": false },
//     { "num": 3, "odd": true },

TITLE: Query Introspection with Jora's Stat Mode in JavaScript
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use Jora's stat mode for query introspection. This mode allows for fetching values passed through a location in a query and obtaining suggestions for query completion. It's particularly useful when combined with the tolerant mode for handling incomplete queries.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/api.md#2025-04-18_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

const query = jora('...query...', { stat: true });
const statApi = query(data);
// { stat() { ... }, suggestion() { ... }, ... }
```

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

const query = jora('.[foo=""]', { stat: true });
const statApi = query([{ id: 1, foo: "hello" }, { id: 2, foo: "world" }]);

statApi.stat(3);
// [
//   {
//     context: 'path',
//     from: 2,
//     to: 5,
//     text: 'foo',
//     values: Set(2) { [Object], [Object] },
//     related: null
//   }
// ]

statApi.suggestion(3); // .[f|oo=""]
// [
//   {
//     type: 'property',
//     from: 2,
//     to: 5,
//     text: 'foo',
//     suggestions: [ 'id', 'foo' ]
//   }
// ]

statApi.suggestion(7); // .[foo="|"]
// [
//   {
//     type: 'value',
//     from: 6,
//     to: 8,
//     text: '""',
//     suggestions: [ 'hello', 'world' ]
//   }
// ]
```

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';

const query = jora('.[foo=]', {
    stat: true,
    tolerant: true // without the tolerant option a query compilation
                   // will raise a parse error:
                   // .[foo=]
                   // ------^
});
const statApi = query([{ id: 1, foo: "hello" }, { id: 2, foo: "world" }]);

statApi.suggestion(6); // .[foo=|]
// [
//   {
//     type: 'value',
//     from: 6,
//     to: 6,
//     text: '',
//     suggestions: [ 'hello', 'world' ]
//   },
//   {
//     type: 'property',
//     from: 6,
//     to: 6,
//     text: '',
//     suggestions: [ 'id', 'foo' ]
//   }
// ]
```

TITLE: Analyzing npm dependencies with Jora to find multiple package versions
DESCRIPTION: This script uses jora to analyze the output of 'npm ls --all --json' and identify paths to packages that have multiple versions in the dependency tree. It executes the npm command, parses the JSON output, applies a complex jora query, and prints the result as a tree.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/README.md#2025-04-18_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
import jora from 'jora';
import { exec } from 'child_process';

function printTree() {
    // see implementation in examples/npm-ls.js
}

exec('npm ls --all --json', (error, stdout) => {
    if (error) {
        return;
    }

    const npmTree = JSON.parse(stdout);
    const depsPathsToMultipleVersionPackages = jora(`
        $normalizedDeps: => dependencies.entries().({ name: key, ...value });
        $multiVersionPackages:
            ..$normalizedDeps()
            .group(=>name, =>version)
            .({ name: key, versions: value.sort() })
            .[versions.size() > 1];

        $pathToMultiVersionPackages: => .($name; {
            name,
            version,
            otherVersions: $multiVersionPackages[=>name=$name].versions - version,
            dependencies: $normalizedDeps()
                .$pathToMultiVersionPackages()
                .[name in $multiVersionPackages.name or dependencies]
        });

        $pathToMultiVersionPackages()
    `)(npmTree);

    printTree(depsPathsToMultipleVersionPackages);
});
```

SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/object-literal.md#2025-04-18_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$users: [
    { id: 1, name: 'Alice' },
    { id: 2, name: 'Bob' }
];

$users.({
    ..., // The same as ...$
    active: true
})

// Result: [
//     { "id": 1, "name": "Alice", "active": true },
//     { "id": 2, "name": "Bob", "active": true }
// ]
```

TITLE: JavaScript Equivalent of Product Grouping Jora Query
DESCRIPTION: A JavaScript function that implements the same product grouping logic as the Jora query, identifying popular tags and grouping products based on how many popular tags they match.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/complex-examples.md#2025-04-18_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: javascript
CODE:
```
function getProductsSortedByPopularTags(data) {
    const popularTags = data.products
        .flatMap(product => product.tags)
        .reduce((acc, tag) => {
            acc[tag] = (acc[tag] || 0) + 1;
            return acc;
        }, {})
        .entries()
        .sort((a, b) => b[1] - a[1])
        .slice(0, 5)
        .map(entry => entry[0]);

    const productsWithPopularTagsCount = data.products.map(product => {
        const popularTagsMatchCount = product.tags.filter(tag => popularTags.includes(tag)).length;
        return {
            ...product,
            popularTagsMatchCount
        };
    });

    const sortedProducts = productsWithPopularTagsCount.sort((a, b) => {
        if (b.popularTagsMatchCount !== a.popularTagsMatchCount) {
            return b.popularTagsMatchCount - a.popularTagsMatchCount;
        }

        if (a.category !== b.category) {
            return a.category.localeCompare(b.category);
        }

        return a.price - b.price;
    });

    const groupedProducts = sortedProducts.reduce((acc, product) => {
        if (!acc[product.popularTagsMatchCount]) {
            acc[product.popularTagsMatchCount] = [];
        }

        acc[product.popularTagsMatchCount].push({
            name: product.name,
            category: product.category,
            price: product.price
        });

        return acc;
    }, {});

    return Object.entries(groupedProducts).map(([popularTagsCount, products]) => ({
        popularTagsCount: Number(popularTagsCount),
        products
    }));
}
```

TITLE: Basic Array Slicing in Jora
DESCRIPTION: Extracts elements from an array using slice notation with start and end indices. This example takes elements from index 1 (inclusive) to index 4 (exclusive).
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/articles/slice-notation.md#2025-04-18_snippet_0

TITLE: Book Listing with Filtered and Ranked Tags using Jora
DESCRIPTION: This complex Jora query processes a data object containing books, authors, tags, and reviews. It returns a list of books matching a specified tag filter, including the book title, author name, tags, and the top review. The query demonstrates complex data relationships, filtering, and sorting in Jora.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/complex-examples.md#2025-04-18_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: jora
CODE:
```
$authors;
$tags;
$reviews;

books
  .({ 
    $bookId: id;
    $authorId;
    $author: $authors[=> id = $authorId];
    $tagIds;

    title,
    author: $author.name,
    tags: $tags.[id in $tagIds].name,
    topReview: $reviews
      .[bookId = $bookId]
      .min(rating desc, date desc)
      | { 
        rating,
        text: `${text[0:150]}...`
      }
  })
  .[tags has #.tagFilter]
  .sort(topReview.rating desc, title asc)
```

TITLE: Equivalent JavaScript Function for Book Listing
DESCRIPTION: This JavaScript function replicates the functionality of the complex Jora query for book listing. It processes the input data, filters books by tag, maps the required information, and sorts the results based on review ratings and book titles.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/complex-examples.md#2025-04-18_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: js
CODE:
```
function getMappedBooks(inputData, tagFilter) {
    const { books, authors, tags, reviews } = inputData;
    
    const filteredBooks = books
        .map(book => {
            const author = authors.find(author => author.id === book.authorId);
            const bookTags = tags.filter(tag => book.tagIds.includes(tag.id));
            
            const bookReviews = reviews.filter(review => review.bookId === book.id);
            const sortedReviews = bookReviews.sort((a, b) => {
                const ratingDiff = b.rating - a.rating;
                if (ratingDiff !== 0) {
                    return ratingDiff;
                }
                return new Date(b.date) - new Date(a.date);
            });
            const topReview = sortedReviews[0] && {
                rating: sortedReviews[0].rating,
                text: `${sortedReviews[0].text.slice(0, 150)}...`
            };
            
            return {
                title: book.title,
                author: author.name,
                tags: bookTags.map(tag => tag.name),
                topReview: topReview
            };
        })
        .filter(mappedBook => tagFilter.some(tag => mappedBook.tags.includes(tag)))
        .sort((a, b) => {
            const ratingDiff = b.topReview.rating - a.topReview.rating;
            if (ratingDiff !== 0) {
                return ratingDiff;
            }
            return a.title.localeCompare(b.title);
        });
    
    return filteredBooks;
}
```

TITLE: Equivalent jq Query for Book Listing
DESCRIPTION: This jq query replicates the functionality of the complex Jora query for book listing. It processes the input data, maps the required information, filters books by tag, and sorts the results based on review ratings and book titles.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/complex-examples.md#2025-04-18_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: jq
CODE:
```
.books
| map({
    title: .title,
    author: (.authorId as $aid | .authors[] | select(.id == $aid).name),
    tags: (.tagIds | map(. as $tid | .tags[] | select(.id == $tid).name)),
    topReview: (
        .id as $bid
        | .reviews
        | map(select(.bookId == $bid))
        | sort_by(-.rating, .date)
        | .[0]
        | {
            rating: .rating,
            text: (.text | .[0:150] + "...")
        }
    )
})
| map(select(.tags | any(. as $t | .[] == $t)))
| sort_by(.topReview.rating, .title)
```

TITLE: jq Equivalent of Product Grouping Jora Query
DESCRIPTION: A jq script that implements the same product grouping logic as the Jora query, with functions for identifying popular tags and counting matches.
SOURCE: https://github.com/discoveryjs/jora/blob/master/docs/complex-examples.md#2025-04-18_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: jq
CODE:
```
def popular_tags:
  group_by(.tags[]) | map({tag: .[0].tags[], count: length}) | sort_by(-.count) | .[0:5] | map(.tag);

def product_info: { name, category, price };

def popular_tags_match_count(tags, popularTags): length(tags | map(select(. as $tag | popularTags | index($tag) != null)));

def sorted_products(popularTags):
  map({ product: ., popularTagsMatchCount: (popular_tags_match_count(.tags, popularTags)) }) | sort_by(-.popularTagsMatchCount, .product.category, .product.price);

{
  popularTags: (popular_tags),
  groupedProducts: (sorted_products(popular_tags))
    | group_by(.popularTagsMatchCount)
    | map({ popularTagsCount: .[0].popularTagsMatchCount, products: [.[] | .product | product_info] })
}
